title: What Chefs Are Serving This Thanksgiving: Recipes for a Five-Star Relish Tray
sub_head: Simple and satisfying—and a light lift for the host—the Midwestern-style relish tray has always been the height of low-key hospitality. Now, a renaissance is under way at restaurants around the country.
body:
FILE UNDER Grandma knows best. Before Instagram discovered the charcuterie board, there was the relish tray. Remember? The cut-glass dish or silver platter that graced the table twice a year, with compartments tailor-made for stacks of crisp carrot spears and frilly celery sticks, sunny deviled eggs, piles of briny piccalilli, pickled beets and peppery radishes?
Depending on which corner of the country you hail from, you might call it crudités, or a grazing plate. At our ’80s-era holiday dinners outside Hartford, Conn., my cousins and I didn’t call it anything at all—we just nibbled the jumbo black olives off our fingertips while the grown-ups sipped Manhattans. Whatever moniker you use, nostalgia aside, this snappy spread of fresh veggies, piquant pickles, crunchy crackers and creamy dips remains one of the best big-enjoyment, low-effort ways to kick off a celebratory feast.
